Carboxylic acid derivatives boiling point and solubility

Acyl chlorides and esters have lower boiling points than the parent carboxylic acids as a result of their inability to form intermolecular hydrogen bonds with their own molecule.

Esters are generally insoluble in polar solvents but soluble in non-polar solvents. Acyl chlorides are insoluble in non-polar solvents and soluble in water. Solubility in water is dependent on the size of the hydrocarbon chain.
Acyl chloride can also undergo alkaline hydrolysis with \(NaOH\) instead of water to produce a carboylate salt with \(OH\) replaced by \(O^-Na^+\).

Boiling point generally increases with increasing \(M_r\). Among isomeric amines, boiling point increases in the following order: \(3^\circ<2^\circ<1^\circ\) amines. Amines have higher boiling points than alkanes due to hydrogen bonding, and lower boiling points than alcohols due to weaker hydrogen bond (less polar).

Amines can form hydrogen bonds with water and are soluble in water. Higher members have poorer solubility because they have relatively large non-polar hydrocarbon portions.

Amine can act as Bronsted-Lowry base or Lewis base. The strength as a base is dependent on the availability of the lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom to form a dative bond.

Gaseous phase


Aqueous solution

Amides are polar organic compounds. Compared to \(3^\circ\) amides, \(1^\circ\) and \(2^\circ\) amides have higher melting and boiling points due to the presence of hydrogen bonding. \(3^\circ\) amide molecules do not form hydrogen bonds since there is no hydrogen directly bonded to the electronegative N atom.

Lower members of aliphatic amides are soluble in water because they can interact with water molecules via hydrogen bonding. Solubility of amides in water decreases with increasing size of the non-polar hydrocarbon chain.

The lack of basicity in amides arises because the orbital containing the lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom overlaps with the \(\pi\) electron cloud of the adjacent C=O bond and the lone pair of electrons is delocalised, and they are not available for coordination to a proton.
Amides can undergo reduction to form amines using \(LiAlH_4\) in dry ether.
With the exception of aminoethanoic acid (glycine), all 2-amino acids display enontiomerism and can exist in optically active forms.
Amino acids are amphoteric since they contain both acidic and basic groups.

A peptide is a compound containing two or more acid resides linked by peptide bonds between the \(\alpha\)-amino group of each acid and the \(\alpha\)-carboxyl group of the neighbouring acid. Each amino acid unit is called an amino acid residue.
Condensation polymers are formed when monomers containing two functional groups come together and lose a small molecule such as \(H_2O\) or \(HCl\).

An electrolyte is a compound which will conduct an electric current when it is in aqueous solution or in molten state, due to the flow of charge carried by its ions.

A strong electrolyte is a compound which fully ionises.
A weak electrolyte is a compound which only partially ionises.
A non-electrolyte is a compound which does not ionise.

If a metal electrode is immersed in an aqueous solution containing a metal oxide, an equilibrium is established which leads to negative charge formation on the electrode. There is a potential difference between the negatively charged metal and the positively charged solution, known as electrode potential.

Temperature
Concentration of ions in aqueous solution
Partial pressure of any gas involved in the reaction

The standard hydrogen electrode consists of a platinum electrode coated with finely divided platinum. It is immersed in a solution where \([H^+]=1mol\ dm^{-3}\), with hydrogen gas at 1 bar bubbled over the platinum electrode and temperature kept at 25℃ or 298K.

Platinum is used because it is inert. The electrode allows \(H_2\) to be adsorbed on its surface and establish the following equilibrium (potential on the platium electrode is arbitrarily assigned a value of 0.00V):\[2H^++2e^-\rightleftharpoons H_2,\ E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}=0.00V\]

The standard electrode potential of a half-cell is the electromotive force, measured at 298K, between the half-cell and the standard hydrogen electrode, in which the concentration of any reacting species in solution is \(1mol\ dm^{-3}\) and any gaseous species is at a pressure of 1 bar.

\(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}\) values give an indication of the position of equilibrium of reaction. A more positive/negative \(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}\) value indicates that the position of equilibrium lies to the right/left. The forward/backward reaction is favoured, the more likely reduction/oxidation occurs, the higher the tendency to gain/lose electrons, and the stronger the oxidising/reducing agent.

The standard cell potential is the potential difference between two half-cells under standard conditions, and give a measure of the e.m.f. of the cell.\[E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}_{cell}=E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}_{cathode}-E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}_{anode}\]\(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}_{cathode}\) is the reduction potential of the half-cell undergoing reduction.
\(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}_{anode}\) is the reduction potential of the half-cell undergoing oxidation.

The relationship between \(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}\) and \(G^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}\) is:\[\Delta G^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}=-nFE^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}\]n is the number of moles of electrons transferred in the redox reaction.
F is the Faraday constant.

Kinetic factor is not taken into consideration. \(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}_{cell}\) is a measure of the position of equilibrium but gives no indication of rate.

Reaction takes place under non-standard conditions. \(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}_{cell}\) is the cell potential at standard conditions, predictions under non-standard conditions may not be valid.

Side reaction may occur. If a side reaction occurs, especially with insoluble ionic solid formation, a non-spontaneous reaction may become spontaneous.

(Important for QA)
Hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell, advantages and disadvantages

Advantages
- Able to attain maximum power with minimum weight and volume
- High efficiency of conversion of chemical energy to electrical energy
- Fuel cells do not 'go dead' as reactants are supplied continuously and products are continually removed
- The product of reaction is non-polluting

Disadvantages
- Expensive due to the use of Pt as catalyst at the graphite electrodes
- Most fuels require a high temperature to react in a fuel cell
- Hydrogen is potentially explosive

The process of passing electricity (from an external source) to force a non-spontaneous redox reaction to occur is called electrolysis. The cell in which electrolysis occurs is called the electrolytic cell.

The cation or anion that is discharged is the one that requires the least energy. This is called selective/preferential discharge.

Factors in order:
1. Physical state of electrolyte (molten or aqueous) - molten preferred
2. Electrode potential - more positive/less negative preferred for reduction, less positive/more negative preferred for oxidation
3. Relative concentration of the species - higher concentration can override small differences in standard electrode potential by shifting equilibrium
4. Nature of the electrodes (inert vs reactive) - reactive electrode must be considered if present in electrolysis reactions

Coating aluinium objects with aluminium oxide via electrolysis is called anodising. The advantages are to protect the metal from corrosion, that the anodic film is hard and resistant to wear and a good electrical insulator, and that the film can be dyed to give colour-anodised alumnium.
The impurities in copper obtained from ores reduce the electrical conductivity, so it must be purified before being used for electrical wires.
The mass of substance and/or volume of gas liberated during electrolysis is directly proportional to the amount of charge that passed through the cell.

The amount of charge required to discharge 1 mole of an element depends on the charge on the ion. In other words, the number of Faradays required to discharge one mole of an ion at the electrode equals the amount of charge on the ion.
A transition element is a d-block element which can form one or more stable ions with a partially filled d subshell.

The first-row transition elements are all metals and all elements are remarkably similar in their physical properties.

Hard and have high densities
High melting and boiling points
Good conductors of heat and electricity
Transition element atomic radii and ionisation energies

The atomic radii of the first-row transition elements (in particular, from \(V\) to \(Cu\)) in Period 4 are almost constant/relatively invariant.

The first ionisation energies of the transition elements from \(Ti\) to \(Cu\) is almost constant/relatively invariant.
Transition element melting and boiling points

Comparing s-block and transition elements, the melting point of transition elements are generally higher than the s-block elements in the same period.

The valence 3d and 4s electrons are close in energy. Both 3d and 4s electrons are available for delocalisation into the sea of electrons. With a greater number of delocalised electrons and higher charge density of the cations, the metallic bonding is stronger in the transition elements.

Comparing s-block and transition elements, the transition elements are generally much denser than the s-block elements in the same period.

Transition elements have smaller atomic size/radius and thus have more atoms per unit volume, larger atomic mass compared to s-block elements. Transition elements have greater mass per unit volume compared to s-block elements.

Transition elements form compounds in which the transition element shows a variety of oxidation states while s-block elements form compounds in which they exist in a fixed oxidation state.

The transition elements form coloured compounds and ions while s-block elements form compounds that are usually white in the solid state and colourless in aqueous solution.

The transition elements and their compounds often show catalytic activity while s-block elements and their compounds show little or no catalytic activity.

The transition elements sgiw a great tendency to form stable complexes while s-block elements show much less tendency to form stable ocmplexes.

Transition elements can show variable oxidation states in their compounds primarily due to the close similarity in energy of the 3d and the 4s electrons, that both the 3d and the 4s electrons are available for bond formation (ionic or covalent).

Lower oxidation states are usually found in ionic compounds.


Higher oxidation states are usually found in species where the transition element is covalently bonded to other more electronegative atoms.

Highest possible oxidation state = no. of unpaired d-electrons + 4s electrons

Oxides of elements in low oxidation states tend to be basic while oxides of elements in high oxidation states tend to be acidic.

Relatively stabilities of different oxidation states are best understood in terms of standard electrode potentials, \(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}(M^{3+}/M^{2+})\).

Going across the transition elements, there is a general increase in \(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}\) value. THere is a decrease in\(E^{\circ\kern-0.65em-}\) value from \(Mn^{3+}/Mn^{2+}\) to \(Fe^{3+}/Fe^{2+}\). Addition of an electron to \(Fe^{3+}\) results in a \(3d^6\) configuration, where there is inter-electronic repulsion between the paired electrons in the same 3d-orbital.

Heterogenous catalyst. The availability of a partially filled 3d subshell allows for ready exchange of electrons to and from reactant molecules, facilitating the formation of weak bonds with the reactant molecules. This is due to the availability of 3d electrons for bond formation with reactant molecules or the availability of low-lying vacant orbitals which can accept electron pairs from the reactant molecules.

Homogenous catalyst. Their ability to exist in different oxidation states and the relative ease of conversion from one oxidation state to another. These features facilitate the formation of, and decomposition of, the intermediate formed from the transition metal ion catalyst and the reactants.

A complex contains a central metal atom or ion linked to one or more surrounding ions or molecules (called ligands) by co-ordinate bond (or dative covalent bond). If species carries an overall charge, it is called a complex ion.

The number of bonds formed with the metal ion exceeds the oxidation state of the metal ion.

The co-ordination number of the central metal ion (or atom) is the total number of co-ordinate bonds that the central metal ion (or atom) forms with ligands.

A ligand is an ion or a molecule which contains at least one atom bearing a lone pair of electrons which can be donated into a low-lying vacant orbital of a central metal atom or ion forming a co-ordinate bond (or dative covalent bond), resulting in the formation of a complex.

The transition metal ions have low-lying vacant orbitals (e.g. 3d, 4s and 4p orbitals) to accommodate the lone pairs of electrons from the ligands to form co-ordinate bonds.

The transition metal ions are relatively small and highly charged. Consequently, they have relatively high charge to size ratio (charge density) and are able to attract the lone pair of electrons from the ligands. Their high charge density and hence polarising power, produces a strong tendency towards covalent bond formation with ligands.

Due to their high charge density, transition metal ions exist as aqua complexes in aqueous solution. Each oxygen atom of a water molecule donates a lone pair of electrons into a low-lying vacant orbital of the transition metal ion and forms a coordinate bond.

Aquous solutions of most transition metal compounds such as \(CrCl_3(aq)\), \(FeCl_3(aq)\), \(CuSO_4(aq)\) and \(Co(NO_3)_2(aq)\) are acidic.
Shape of the complex ion depends on the coordination number and nature of the metal ion.
Factors affecting colour of transition metal complexes (2)

Identity of metal and its oxidation state (depends on the number of d electrons present). Compounds with a different no. of d-electrons repel the electrons of the ligands to different extent, thus the energy gap between the split d-orbitals are different.

Nature of the ligands bonded to the central metal ion/atom. Different ligands split the d orbitals of the metal ion into two sets of slightly different eneergy levels to different extents. Different transition metal complexes absorb different wavelengths of light from the visible spectrum for d-d transitions.

The stability constant, \(K_{stab}\), of a complex ion may be defined as the equilibrium constant for its formation. The greater the value of \(K_{stab}\), the more stable the complex ion is relative to the aqua complex containing the same metal ion.

Haemoglobin is a red pigment in red blood cells, acts as a transporter of oxygen in blood and contains iron(II) which has a co-ordination number of six.

Five co-ordination sites are taken up by \(N\) (4 from porphyrin + 1). The oxygen molecule may become reversibly bonded at the sixth side allowing the haemoglobin to carry oxygen from one part of the body to another. Better ligands than oxygen can bond strongly to the iron(II) and thus destroy the oxygen carrying capacity of haemoglobin, accounting for the toxic nature of \(CO\) and \(CN^-\) ions.
Crystal field theory causes the splitting of the five d-orbitals in octahedral and tetrahedral complexes.
